text.p: Let [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] be a vector space over [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R[/mathjaxinline], and let [mathjaxinline]T: V\rightarrow V[/mathjaxinline] be given by [mathjaxinline]T(v) = 2v[/mathjaxinline].
If we know that [mathjaxinline]T(u) = T(v)[/mathjaxinline], must it be true that [mathjaxinline]u = v[/mathjaxinline]?

solution.font:
If [mathjaxinline]T(u) = T(v)[/mathjaxinline], then [mathjaxinline]2u=2v[/mathjaxinline]. Multiplying by [mathjaxinline]\frac{1}{2}[/mathjaxinline], we see that [mathjaxinline]u=v[/mathjaxinline].
The fact that [mathjaxinline]T(u) = T(v)[/mathjaxinline] implies [mathjaxinline]u=v[/mathjaxinline] is equivalent to the definition of into.
